GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
This species of torrent salamander occur only towards the west slopes of the Cascade Mountains from the west bank of the Skookumchuck River in central Washington, near the Thurston-Lewis County line (McAllister 1995; Green et al. 2013). In Oregon, this species occurs south to the Middle Fork of the Willamette River (Good and wake 1992; Lannoo 2005). Stebbins (2003) noted occurrences in Skamania County, Washington, and Lane County in Oregon. Elevational range for this species is varied, but not entirely understood; populations have been reported at 1219 meters, but most have been studied at around 870 meters (Good and Wake 1992; Lannoo 2005). It is important to note that Cascade torrent salamanders are usually not reported downstream, where gradients are lower and present fewer opportunities for suitable habitat (Hunter 1998). Previous research on larval density in the Columbia River gorge, found the Cascade torrent salamander to have one of the highest density in comparison to any other Rhyacotriton salamander averaging 33.3 larvae/m2 (Nussbaum and Tait 1977). Adults at the same locality by Wahkeena Falls averaged 1.9 adults/m2 (Nijhuis and Kaplan 1998). Egg deposition sites are associated with coarse substrate spaces in slow velocity flow seeps. Larvae have been reported under stones along stream channels and in fissure networks found in the streambed and bank (Nussbaum and Tait 1977).

As adults, preferred habitat includes underground water courses, rocky rubble found in stream banks, fissures by stream banks, and cracks in wet cliffs (Leonard et al. 1993; Corkran and Thoms 1996).

Maximum size of basins where torrent salamanders were reported was 141 ha (348 ac; Hunter 1998).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
Ranges from the Olympic Mountains and Cascade Mountains of Washington, Oregon, and California (Behler and King 1979). This mountain-ranging species usually found in open coniferous forests. Will use ponds, streams, potholes in meadows, and lakes, Found in association with water among grasses, ferns, other low-laying herbaceous growth, often ranges into the timberline. Breeding occurs in permanent and temporary lentic water bodies, sometimes in small bodies of water in the vicinity of larger lakes (Nussbaum et al. 1983). Breeding areas in Olympic National Park, Washington are generally characterized by muddy and silty substrates, with low UV-B percolation, and devoid of fish (Adams et al. 2001).
Its range is restricted to the Cascades Mountains from north Washington south to Feather River in north Butte County, California. In California, its distribution is limited to the tributaries of the Salmon, Scott, and Trinity Reservoirs that drain into the coast; Also the drainages of McCloud, Pit, Mill, and Big Butte Creeks that drain into the Sacramento River (Stebbins 2003). This species is considered common in Olympic and Mount Rainier national parks (Tyler et al. 2002). This species was one of the first to recolonize post eruption in Mount St. Helens Volcanic Monument in the southern Washington Cascades (Crisafulli and Hawkins 1998).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
Columbia torrent salamanders occur only in coastal and near coastal portions of northwestern Oregon and southwestern Washington. Populations extend from the Little Nestucca River system in Tillamook County, Oregon, and the Chehalis River in Gray’s Harbor County, Washington (Good and Wake 1992; McAllister 1995). This species is found from near sea level to the highest point in their range, Boisfort Peak at 948 meters in the Willapa Hills of southwestern Washington, and in Saddleback Mountain at 1001 meters in the coast ranges of northwestern Oregon (Green et al. 2013). The species is also found in a few of the upper reaches of the coastal region of the Willamette basin, to include the Upper Grand Ronde system in Oregon (Good et al. 1987).
Habitat includes near coastal perennial headwater streams found within a managed forest (Wilkins and Peterson 2000). This species was reported more frequent in streams of basalt formations than in streams on marine sediments. Egg deposition sites include sandstone sites on side slope seeps (Russel et al. 2002).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
Three subspecies of Spotted Owl (Strix occidentalis) are recognized: Northern Spotted Owl (S. o. caurina), California Spotted Owl (S. o. occidentalis), and Mexican Spotted Owl (S. o. lucida).  Among the three subspecies, the following habitats are used: western hemlock (Tsuga heterophylla), mixed evergreen, mixed conifer, Douglas-fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii), redwood (Sequoia sempervirens), Douglas-fir/hardwood, evergreen hardwood, pine (Pinus)-oak (Quercus), ponderosa pine (Pinus ponderosa), riparian, western redcedar (Thuja plicata), and other forest types, as well as steep, rocky canyons in different parts of its range (Gutierrez et al. 1995).

Gutierrez et al. 1995 reported an elevation limit of up to 1,200 m in the Northwest and 2,700 m in the Southwest (Gutierrez et al. 1995).

Northern Spotted Owls inhabit mature, mixed conifer forests with complex structure for nesting. (Gutierrez et al. 1995).  They roost in portions of forest where canopy closure is high and multiple subcanopy layers exist (Gutierrez et al. 1995).  Foraging habitat is similar to roosting habitat and occurs in managed and unmanaged forests (Gutierrez et al. 1995).  Winter habitat is the same as summer, but use of stands with a larger tanoak (Lithocarpus densiflorus) and oak component was documented in the KIamath region. (Gutierrez et al. 1995).  In northern California, they prefer steep-sided canyons with north-facing slopes (Zeiner et al. 1990).

California Spotted Owls also inhabit forests with complex structure; from low elevation hardwood (oak) forests to high elevation conifer forests.  Like the Northern Spotted Owl, they use areas with lots of tree diameter classes represented and high canopy closure.  The presence of some trees > 90 cm dbh are a critical component of nesting habitat but owls forage in stands without these large trees (Gutierrez et al. 1995).  Some individuals of this subspecies migrate short distances to lower elevation Sierra Nevada hardwood riparian forests (Gutierrez et al. 1995).  They utilize smaller forest stands, with more shrubs and deciduous species (Gutierrez et al. 1995).  

Mexican Spotted Owls are found in forested slopes with rocky outcrops and heavily forested areas in areas of the Southwest (Ganey et al. 2011).  In the Southern Rockies, the most important forest type is mixed-conifer (e.g., Douglas-fir, white fir, ponderosa pine, limber pine, southwestern white pine), but pine-oak, ponderosa pine, and riparian communities are used for roosting and nesting as well.  Gambel oak is an important habitat component and trees with large dbh are utilized for roosting and nesting (Ganey et al. 2011).  Although canopy cover and tree dbh are important, high tree density does not appear to be important for this subspecies (Ganey et al. 2011).  They show a strong preference for old-growth forests and moderate to heavy canopy closure (>40%; Gutierrez et al. 1995 and Ganey et al. 2011).   Rocky canyonlands are suitable habitat for Mexican Spotted Owls in some areas provided they have steep narrow canyons with perennial water.  Such canyonlands usually but don’t always contain patches of trees (conifer or riparian forests; Gutierrez et al. 1995).  In these areas, topography and geology are more influential on owl distribution than vegetation (Ganey et al. 2011).  In the Basin and Range ecoregion, Mexican Spotted Owls occur in evergreen oak woodlands, Madrean pine-oak forests, and Arizona cypress forests (Ganey et al. 2011).

Gutierrez et al. 1995 reported that owls in California require forest blocks of 40-240 ha (100-600 ac) (Gutierrez et al. 1995).  N. Tarr, 12June2013.

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description: Fratercula cirrhata winters on the open ocean (Grinnell and Miller, 1944; Piatt and Kitaysky, 2002). In summer the species can be found nesting on steep, grassy slopes, cliffs, or rock outcrops on undisturbed islands or, occasionally, on the mainland (Grinnell and Miller, 1944; Vermeer, 1979; DeSante and Ainley, 1980; McChesney et al., 1995; Piatt et al., 1997; St. Clair et al., 2001; Piatt and Kitaysky, 2002; Addison et al., 2007), while it forages in open water (Zeiner et al., 1990).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
Northwest:
This specialized arboreal rodent occupies old-growth, damp, coastal forests of Oregon and extreme northern California at elevations up to 1600 meters eating almost exclusively Douglas fir needles (Wilson and Ruff 1999, Manning and Maguire 1999). The precise limits to the range in California are uncertain (Hayes 1996) - from NatureServe "Murray (1995) presented DNA information suggesting that specimens from south of the Smith River drainage in Del Norte County, California, were more similar to the Oregon tree voles than to other California populations." Although their diet is largely composed of Douglas fir needles, this species is known to inhabit a variety of mesic forests/tree species including , grand fir western hemlock, and Sitka spruce (Verts and Carraway 1998).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description: The Blanco blind salamander is originally described from a single specimen from 1951 as workers were drilling a hole for water in the bed of the Blanco River east of San Marcos in Hays County Texas (see Lannoo 2005 on authorship). Little information is available on habitat and egg deposition sites other than being subterranean and aquatic (Green et al. 2013).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description: The Cascade Caverns salamander is described from the Cascade Caverns in Kendall County, Texas (Smith and Potter 1946). This single population consists of individuals displaying a wide spectrum of morphological features, from cave-associated morphologies, to surface-like morphologies (Green et al. 2013). Although, it has been theorized that the shift in morphologies may be due to hybridization with surface-dwelling salamanders, Chippindale et al. (2000) found no evidence of hybrids. This species is only known from caves that contain water and surrounding outflows; individuals are found under submerged rocks, mud substrate, while individuals associated with springs are found under rocks, leaves, and substrate.

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
This species was originally described from Honey Creek Cave in Comal County, Texas (Lannoo 2005; Mitchell and Reddell 1965). Their distribution includes several caves in the Cibolo Sinkhole Plain of the southeastern Edwards Plateau region in Comal and Bexar counties, but probably extends into Kendall County (Chippindale et al. 2000; Green et al. 2013). 
This species is found on mud substrates and rocks in caves (Sweet 1982).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description: The San Marcos salamander is described to occur in outflows of San Marcos Springs in the city of San Marcos, Hays County, Texas (Bishop 1941; Lannoo 2005). These springs have been heavily modified by humans to construct a small lake. More recently, San Marcos salamanders occupy this lake and upstream the San Marcos River in springs at elevations of 174 meters (Green et al. 2013). As adults, this species is completely aquatic and is found in growths of blue algae (Lyngbya sp.), in gravel substrate, under rocks, and in the water column at water depths more than a meter.

references: Enkerlin-Hoeflich, Ernesto C. and Kelly M. Hogan. 1997. Red-crowned Parrot (Amazona viridigenalis), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/292.
GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
Southwest/Great Plains/Southeast:
The red-crowned parrot is native to northeastern Mexico, but can be found in portions of the southern U.S. These populations are generally escaped or released pets and have been reported for more than 40 years in a number of urban and suburban habitats. Several populations exist throughout southern and central Texas including Brownsville, Harlingen, McAllen, Mission, San Antonio and San Marcos. In Florida, breeding populations are established in Orange, Broward and Dade counties including the cities of Ft. Lauderdale, West Palm Beach, and Miami as well as Key Largo in the northern Florida Keys. In southern California, the species is resident to Los Angeles and Orange counties and south to San Diego. Small numbers have been recorded on the Monterey Peninsula (Roberson and Tenney 1993) and in San Francisco and Sacramento but breeding has not been confirmed (Froke 1981, Am. Ornithol. Union 1983, Lever 1987, Forshaw 1989, Collar et al. 1992, Roberson and Tenney 1993, Small 1994, Garrett 1996).
In the U.S., the red-crowned parrot is typically established in cities and urban areas, and prefers areas with large trees (Enkerlin-Hoeflich and Hogan 1997). Habitat may also include lowland deciduous forest and pine-oak woodlands; this species will also forage in cultivated areas (NatureServe 2009). Typical native habitat includes Tamaulipan scrub, especially in ravines or riparian areas with larger trees, and dry oak-sweet gum forests. Native habitat is generally described as sub-deciduous tropical forest (Enkerlin-Hoeflich and Hogan 1997).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
Great Plains:
Historically, this species range encompasssed 11 counties in north-central Texas and two adjacent counties in Oklahoma north of the Red River (Caire et al. 1989, Schmidly 2004, USFWS 2011). Martin (2002) suggets the current known distribution includes only 5 counties in Texas [Archer, Childress, Hardeman, Motley, and Wichita] (USFWS 2011, Martin 2002). Apparently the last confirmed sighting of this species in Oklahoma was in 1969 (Baumgardner 1987, Moss and Mehlhop-Cifelli 1990, Stangl et al. 1992, WildEarth Guardians 2010, USFWS 2011).
USFWS (2011) describes habitat: "Generally, Texas kangaroo rats inhabit arid areas that are not prone to flooding (Martin 2002, p. 34); are characterized  by short, sparse grasses (Dalquest and Collier 1964, p. 147; Goetze  et al.  2007, p. 18; Nelson  et al. 2009, p. 126); and contain little woody canopy cover (Goetze  et al.  2007, p. 18). Texas kangaroo rats prefer areas where the soil contains a sufficient clay component to support their burrows (Bailey 1905, p. 149; Dalquest and Collier 1964, p. 148; Roberts and Packard 1973, p. 958; Martin and Matocha 1991, p. 355; Goetze et al. 2007, p. 17), although it is not exclusively restricted to such soils (Martin and Matocha 1991, p. 355). Their burrows are often associated with Prosopis  spp. (mesquite trees) (Dalquest and Collier 1964, p. 147; Martin and  Matocha 1972, p. 875), although  subsequent research has suggested this association may be circumstantial (Stangl  et al. 1992b, p. 31; Goetze  et al. 2007, p. 20; Nelson  et al. 2009, p. 128). For dust bathing, Texas kangaroo rats require areas of bare ground that may not be available in patches of dense vegetation (Goetze et al. 2008, pp. 312-313; Nelson  et al.  2009, p. 127). As such, the Texas kangaroo rat appears to opportunistically burrow in minimally disturbed areas (Stangl et al. 1992b, pp. 25-35; Goetze et al. 2007, p. 19; Nelson  et al. 2009, pp. 128-129)."

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
The distribution of the spot-tailed earless lizard is restricted to central and southern Texas and adjacent northern Mexico. In Mexico, this lizard occurs in northeastern Coahuila, northern Nuevo Leon, and extreme northwestern Tamaulipas (Axtell 1968; Conant and Collins 1991; Dixon 2000). The regions is primarily composed of desert habitat, sand dunes, shrubland, chaparral, and mixed woodland.

This species burrows in or using soil, decaying logs, and leaf litter; eggs are laid underground. The habitat of preference includes open prairie-brushland zones, fairly flat areas with sparse vegetation (open meadows, old and new fields, cleared and disturbed areas, prairie savanna, graded roadways). Within its range it is associated with oak-juniper woodlands and mesquite-cacti associations (Axtell 1968; Bartlett and Bartlett 1999).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description: Entirely aquatic amphibians, hellbenders inhabit large, fast-moving streams at elevations below 762 m (Petranka).  They are frequently captured in shallow, rocky rapids.  Hellbenders are most abundant in water that is clear and has many large, flat rocks for shelter, nesting, and breeding.  Other large submerged objects, such as logs, and bank holes in or at water's edge may also be used for shelter.  Stream siltation and chemical or thermal pollution pose possible threats for this species.  Typically, only streams in predominantly forested watersheds provide the cool, well-oxygenated stream conditions required by hellbenders. Hellbender presence in streams is positively correlated with forested buffer width (Graham et al. 2011).  Usually avoids water warmer than 20 C.  Males prepare nests beneath large flat rocks or submerged logs.  Under rocks in medium to large streams with cool, well oxygenated water.  They have become harder to find in northern mountains recently, but are still common in several larger, clean streams.  Hellbenders lay eggs in late summer or fall.  Winter breeding has been observed in Spring River, Arkansas (Peterson et al. 1989).  Clutch size averages about 350-500; increases with female body length.  Several females may oviposit in same site.  Males guard developing eggs. Larvae hatch in 1.5-3 months and lose gills about 18 months after hatching.  Sexually mature in 5-8 years (Minton 1972, Peterson et al. 1988).  Lifespan of 25+ years.  S. Smith 18Feb05

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
The range is mainly the areas of west-central and southwestern Illinois. Illinois chorus frogs were widespread prior to extensive modification in the vicinity of the Illinois and Mississippi Rivers between the late 1800s and early 1900s (Lannoo 2005). This species is considered uncommon with a reported small number (less than 10) individuals calling per site (Herkert 1992; Brown and Rose 1988; Tucker and Philipp 1993). The Illinois chorus frog is listed as Threatened in Illinois, a Species of Special Concern in Arkansas, and Rare in Missouri (Lannoo 2005).

There is evidence of a strong association with sand prairies of Illinois, or at least have a requirement for sandy substrate (Brown and Brown 1973; Axtell and Haskell 1977). Significant amount of time is spent burrowed in areas without dense vegetation (Brown et al. 1972). Breeding habitat in Illinois are mainly flooded depressions in fields, but other flooded areas are also utilized (Brown and Rose 1988).

Also Klaus & Buehler (2001) identify slope parameters for NC as ranging from 13-37 degrees which could be to restricted so again, went liberal and just exlcuded flat summits, slope bottoms. GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
Myotis lucifugus is known to hibernate in caves (Davis and Hitchcock, 1965; Fenton and Barclay, 1980). During the summer, the species roosts in: barns and other buildings (Cagle and Cockrum, 1943; Davis and Hitchcock, 1965; Buchler, 1976; Humphrey and Cope, 1976; Anthony and Kunz, 1977; Anthony et al., 1981; Barclay, 1982; Henry et al., 2002); in trees cavities and under sloughing bark (Humphrey and Cope, 1976; Schowalter et al., 1979; Barclay and Cash, 1985; Crampton and Barclay, 1996; Kalcounis and Hecker, 1996; Chung-MacCoubrey, 1999); and in caves (Davis and Hitchcock, 1965; Worthington, 1991; Ports and Bradley, 1996; Agosta et al., 2005). Tree roosts are often in Populus spp. and have been documented within stands of aspen and spruce (Barclay and Cash, 1985; Crampton and Barclay, 1996; Kalcounis and Hecker, 1996), spruce-fir and spruce-fir-birch forests (Broders and Forbes, 2004), and riparian cottonwood forest (Chung-MacCoubrey, 1999).

The small brown myotis has been documented foraging over: sewage lagoons (Worthington, 1991; Tigner and Stukel, 2003); brush and openings in the forest canopy (Buchler, 1976); rivers, streams, ponds, and lakes (Fenton, 1970; Lunde and Harestead, 1986; Saunders and Barclay, 1992; Feldhammer et al., 2009; Clare et al., 2011); in upper canopy of northeastern deciduous forest (Buchler, 1980); ponderosa pine forest (Herd and Fenton, 1983); fields adjacent to water (Herd and Fenton, 1983); and riparian cottonwoods and shrubs (Saunders and Barclay, 1992).

The species has been documented in the following habitats: southern IL oak-hickory (Carroll et al., 2002; Feldhammer et al., 2009); open fields (Fenton, 1970; Moosam et al., 2012); roads (Moosam et al., 2012); subalpine low shrubland with sagebrush and aspen (Foster et al., 1997); subalpine grassland with spruce and aspen (Foster et al., 1997); willows and aspen (Lengas, 1994 as cited in Oliver, 2000); riparian willows and aspen (Lengas, 1994 as cited in Oliver, 2000); mixed conifer forest with willow and aspen (Lengas, 1994 as cited in Oliver, 2000); riparian cottonwood and willow (Ports and Bradley, 1996); high elevation conifer forests in Nevada, with juniper, white fir, subalpine fir, spruce, pinyon pine, limber pine, and bristlecone pine (Ports and Bradley, 1996); deciduous forest (NV) of aspen, cottonwood, shrubs (Ports and Bradley, 1996); ponds with willow or spruce-fir woodland (Storz and Williams, 1996); and closed canopy riparian elm and cottonwood (Kunz, 1973). Neither roosting nor foraging was specifically documented in these studies, so these occurrences may represent transient individuals or merely passage en route to/from roost or forage sites.

Findley et al. (1975) asserted that those individuals not within proximity to large, permanent water bodies were transients. Direct observation confirms maximum distances of roughly 2000 m between roost sites and forage sites or water sources (Buchler, 1976; Davis and Hitchcock, 1965; Humphrey and Cope, 1976; Lunde and Harestead, 1986; Broders et al., 2006).

The species avoids open grasslands and meadows (Schowalter et al., 1979; Storz and Williams, 1996) and clearcuts (Lunde and Harestead, 1986) and is seldom known to forage within forests (Lunde and Harestead, 1986; Saunders and Barclay, 1992; Crampton and Barclay, 1996), with Buchler (1980) and Herd and Fenton (1983) providing the only evidence of such activity.

Elevation constraints are not documented for the eastern U.S., though it has been observed as low as 150 m and up to 760 m in Maryland and Pennsylvannia (Agosta et al., 2005). Western individuals have been documented at elevations ranging from 1311 m in Utah (Oliver, 2000) to 3700 m in CO (Storz and Williams, 1996). Expert review for the Southwest Regional Gap Analysis Project indicated the species presence down to 1157 m.

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
The range for the blanding’s turtle extends from Great Lakes region; ranges from Minnesota, southeastern South Dakota, and central Nebraska eastward through Iowa, northern Missouri, northern and central Illinois, Wisconsin, Michigan (both upper and lower peninsulas), northern and southwestern Indiana, and northern Ohio to northwestern Pennsylvania, northern New York, southeastern Ontario, and southwestern Quebec, with disjunct populations in southeastern New York, eastern New England (Massachusetts to southern Maine), and Nova Scotia (mostly in Kejimkujik National Park) (Conant and Collins 1991; Harding 1997; Herman et al. 1995; Iverson 1992; Vogt 1981). The largest breeding population in the entire range may be supported in the bottomlands of the Upper Mississippi River near Kellogg in Wabasha County in Minnesota (Kofron and Schreiber 1985, McCoy 1973).

The species prefers prairie marshes in the western and southern parts of its range (Bleakney 1958).The species was more widespread on the central prairies of Illinois, Iowa, and Kansas before the extensive wet prairie marshes were drained. Remains are common in archeological sites throughout the present range of the species (McCoy 1973). Eggs are tolerant of dry conditions and relatively high temperatures (Gutzke and Packard 1987). However, Emydoidea blandingii has a very low maximum temperature tolerance (mean = 39.5 C, range 38.2 to 40.6 C) which restricts the turtle's range, and the egg adaptations allow the turtle to use dry, exposed nesting sites (Hutchison et al. 1966). 

In general , suitable habitats for the Blanding’s turtle include marshes, ponds, swamps, lake shallows, backwater sloughs, shallow slow-moving rivers, protected coves and inlets of large lakes, oxbows, and pools adjacent to rivers; waters with soft bottom and aquatic vegetation (Ernst et al. 1994; Kofron and Schreiber 1985; Nyboer 1992). 

Hibernation most often occurs within organic substrate of ponds and creeks (Ross and Anderson 1990). Blanding’s turtles somewhat communal hibernation may be due to scarcity of suitable hibernation sites. Most moved from marshes, shallow ponds, and ditches to deeper ponds after September 1. The deeper ponds probably provide stable water levels during the critical overwintering period and a longer period of warm water temperatures in early fall. Individuals in Missouri hibernated in shallow marsh areas under 15 cm mud below 9.5-21 cm of water (Congdon et al. 1983). Eggs are laid usually in sandy soil in upland areas, usually in warm sunny sites (Congdon et al. 1983). Blanding’s turtles probably nest on available clearings, on sand and gravel bars, and on muskrat lodges or beaver lodges and dams prior to the modification of the landscape by humans (Petokas 1986). Prairie marsh or wet prairie, especially associated with sandy soils, is the preferred habitat in the western part of the range, (Kofron and Schreiber 1985, Nyboer 1992). The primary indicator of juvenile and subadult habitat appears to be Sphagnum (McMaster and Herman 2000). According to McNeil et al. (2000), hatchlings do not seek open water upon emergence from the nest.

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
The range for the Kirtland’s snake includes divided populations in Michigan, Ohio, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky (along the Ohio River valley), and perhaps Missouri. Most recent records for the Great Lakes region are clustered near the southern end of Lake Michigan (Cook County, Illinois; northwestern Indiana; and southwestern Michigan) and in Lucas County, Ohio (Toledo area) (Barbour 1971; Harding 1997). The range has historically included northeastern and central Illinois, most of Indiana and Ohio, north-central Kentucky, southern Michigan, western Pennsylvania, and extreme northeastern Missouri (Conant 1943). 

 This snake can be found in habitats with ample debris on the ground surface; open grassy habitats may harbor populations that are relatively difficult to detect and observe (Minton 2001). The distribution of this snake is centered in urban areas, often in vacant lots associated with streams or wetlands; these are fragments of much larger populations that have been reduced by suburbanization and may now be rapidly reducing (Minton et al. 1983). Although, this species can be locally plentiful in inner city locations (Minton 2001).

 In general, the Kirtland's snake occurs in relict Prairie Peninsula habitats: prairie fens, wet meadows, lakes, wet prairies and associated open and wooded wetlands, seasonal marshes, open swamps, sparsely wooded hillsides, and the vicinity of ponds and sluggish creeks (Wilsmann and Sellers 1988).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description: From NatureServe account: "Gyrinophilus gulolineatus formerly was regarded as a subspecies of G. palleucus; treated as a species by Brandon et al. (1986), Collins and Taggart (2002), and Crother et al. (2000). According to the Environmental Report of the James White Parkway Taskforce (2002; http://web.utk.edu/~nolt/envrepts/JWP.htm), a viable population still exists in Berry Cave, in Roane County. At Mud Flats Cave in western Knox County, habitat has severely degraded recently by silt from the Gettysvue housing development, and recent efforts to find the salamander there have failed; that population may now be extirpated. Two specimens were once found in a ditch near Athens, but nobody knows how they got there or whether they represent some still extant population in that area. The only other place where the salamander has been found is the Meades Quarry/Cruze cave complex in south Knoxville (elevation around 270 m)." Therefore, this Tennesse endemic is extant from only two locations - Berry Cave, Roane County, and an un-named cave near Meades Quarry in Knox County. A cave obligate species, G. gulolineatus prefers inflow (sinkhole) caves over outflow caves because the incoming detritus provides essential nutrients (Beachy 2005).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description: These translucent salamanders are specialized in their habitat requirements and are known to exist only in subterranean streams or pools within limestone caves.  Because of these restrictions, they may be vulnerable any changes within these caves.  Less than 15 localities in Florida [<17 overall] (Means 1992).  Geologic formations containing caves are little known and more localities may exist (Ashton 1988).  Currently known from only a few caves in the Dougherty Plain region of Georgia and Florida.

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description: The Neuse River waterdog is endemic to North Carolina.  Martof et al. (1980) states, 'It inhabits the main streams and larger tributaries of the Neuse and Tar rivers from well above tidewater into the lower piedmont.'  In the Piedmont and along fall line it inhabits moderate to swift flowing streams.  In the coastal plain it is found in or near the main stream of the Neuse and Tar rivers and their major tributaries.  Quiet, backwaters and floodplain swampy areas with large amounts of leaf litter covering the substrate have been identified by some as the principal habitat of this species (Martof et al. 1980, Wilson 1995).  However, others identify main channels of moderately sized streams with hard-clay substrate as the waterdog's primary dwelling place (Petranka 1998).  From the studies leading to these differing observations, it is clear that the entire body of water is utilized, perhaps in support of different eco-biological functions.  They require relatively high oxygen levels and water quality (Ashton 1990).  Eggs are attached to the undersides of objects in water.  Much or their habitat has been lost due to rapid and large-scale development and construction impoundments.   Eggs are probably laid in the spring and hatch in June-July.  Paedomorphic, sexual maturity attained in about 6 years.

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description: "The Oklahoma salamander inhabits small creeks and springs which have loose gravel. It is usually found in the loose gravel but also has been found in aquatic vegetation growing in their cold water creeks." (Wilson 1995). They prefer shallow, slow-flowing areas with medium-sized rocks of low to moderate embeddedness near stream margins where aquatic invertebrate prey are abundant (Tumlison et al. 1990, Petranka 1998). Because they require cold, clean, rocky and/or gravelly, creeks and springs, any activites that degrade water quality will have negative effects on this species (Wilson 1995). E. tynerensis is closely associated with Ordovician-Silurian strata (Tumlison and Cline 2003), and is generally found in streams at elevations below 305 meters (Bury et al. 1980).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description: Streamside salamanders occur in upland deciduous forests in regions of rolling topography.  They are primarily restricted to limestone regions and are rarely found where forest has been eliminated (Petranka 1998).  Breeding occurs in first- and second-order streams and, occasionally, farm ponds, sink hole ponds, and quarry ponds (Craddock and Minckley 1964; Petranka 1982).  Adults are fossorial and rarely found above ground outside the breeding season.  Found as far as 300 to 400 m from the nearest stream (Petranka 1998).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description: The striped newt is endemic to northern Florida and the adjacent Coastal Plain of Georgia.  Adult newts are terrestrial, occupying forested environments in sandhill communities, longleaf pine forest, and pine flatwoods.   The efts wander, typical into high and mesophytic hammocks on well-drained soil, rosemary scrub, turkey oak, and high pine (Christman 1992; Mecham 1967).  They require a breeding habitat of isolated, ephemeral ponds, such as sinkholes, cypress or bay ponds, within sandhill and flatwoods communities (Ashton 1988).  They are rarely found with eastern newts.

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description: The Tennessee cave salamander is an aquatic species of cave pools (Mount 1984).  It is restricted to limestone caves containing slow running or still water (Mount 1986) in shallow pools in both rock and sandy substrates.  These uncommon salamanders have a narrow geographic range and, in addition, a very narrow habitat preference, occurring in only a small percentage of caves within their range.

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
The range for the gopher tortoise extends from southeastern United States from southern South Carolina (Clark et al. 2001) through southern Georgia to southern coastal Florida, west through southern Alabama and southeastern Mississippi to eastern Louisiana (Diemer 1989). Occurs on islands off the Gulf coast of Florida as far south as Cape Sable (Kushlan and Mazzotti 1984; Logan 1981; Mushinsky and McCoy 1994). Most common in southern Georgia and northern and central Florida (Diemer 1989), while four disjunct populations occur in South Carolina (Wright 1982). In Georgia, large populations occur in the western Fall Line Sand Hills and the central Tifton Uplands (Landers and Garner 1981); fragmented populations occur in the Coastal Plain with the largest remaining population in Mississippi is in Desoto National Forest (Lohoefener and Lohmeier 1984). A few populations remain at the western edge of the range in eastern Louisiana (Iverson 1992).

Gopher tortoises are fossorial and construct extensive burrow systems as they spend much of the time underground. Eggs are deposited in a characteristic flask-shaped nest cavity which is excavated by the hindlimbs of the female to a depth of about 10-15 cm. Nests are typically placed in the spoil mound immediately outside the female's burrow (Allen and Neil 1951; Arata 1958; Butler and Hull 1996; Hallinan 1923; Landers et al. 1980; Mount 1975). The diet of the gopher tortoise consists of primarily grasses and other herbaceous plants; sometimes including insects, carrion, and fruits. (Carr 1952; Garner and Landers 1981).

In general, the gopher tortoise prefers habitats with a well-drained sandy substrate, ample herbaceous vegetation for food, and sunlit areas for nesting (Diemer 1989; Hallinan 1923; Landers et al. 1980). Suitable habitat types include sandhill (pine-turkey oak), sand pine scrub, xeric hammock, pine flatwoods, dry prairie, coastal grasslands and dunes, and mixed hardwood-pine communities (Auffenberg and Franz 1982; Kushlan and Mazzotti 1984; Landers and Speake 1980).

The gopher tortoise favors open habitats with a wide variety of herbaceous ground cover vegetation for forage; usually abandons densely canopied areas and frequently can be found in disturbed habitats such as roadsides, fence-rows, old fields, and the edges of overgrown (unburned) uplands (Breininger et al. 1994; Diemer 1989; Stewart et al. 1993).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description: The Peaks of Otter Salamander is closely related to other relict mountaintop Plethodons (P. shenandoah and P. nettingi).   They are locally abundant in mature hardwood forest, mainly on north-facing slopes and in coves in the Peaks of Otter region of west-central Virginia.   They are also found in shaded ravines and rhododendron thickets.  They are generally found above 845 m (Petranka 1998).  They can be found primarily under downed logs and rocks, and among wet leaf litter, in middle to late successional stages of oak-maple woodland (Bury et al. 1980, Mitchell 1991).  They often climb into vegetation, especially ferns, in June-September (Kramer et al. 1993).  They may be vulnerable to habitat fragmentation. They are terrestrial breeders.

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description: Endemic to one relatively small cave system: General Davis Cave, Greenbrier County, southeastern West Virginia (Petranka 1998), this species was previously regarded as an extreme variant of G. porphyriticus by Blaney and Blaney (1978). Limited biochemical information suggests that subterraneus differs from porphyriticus populations (Howard et al. 1984), but further study is warranted. Petranka (1998), Crother et al. (2000), and Collins and Taggart (2002) all treat this as a distinct species. A subterranean obligate, G. subterraneus is limited to limestone-cave stream passages with large amounts of decaying organic matter and occurs in streams and on mud banks margins. Undoubtedly dependent on water quality and availability of organic material flushed into cave from outside (Beachy 2005).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
The range for the red-bellied cooter includes Mid-Atlantic Coastal Plain from central New Jersey to North Carolina; westward in Potomac River to eastern West Virginia, separated populations in Plymouth County, southeastern Massachusetts; questionable record from Naushon Island, Massachusetts introduced and possibly established in New York (Graham 1991).

Habitats include relatively large deep bodies of water: creeks, rivers, marshes, ponds, lakes, sometimes in brackish water while Massachusetts population in ponds only (USFWS 1981). Soft bottom and abundant aquatic vegetation preferred and wanders on land in fall and spring. Eggs are laid usually within 100 yards in nests dug in soft soil in open areas (USFWS 1981).  Nests often in tilled or disturbed soil (DeGraaf and Rudis 1983; Ernst and Barbour 1972).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
The range for the wood turtle extends from Eastern North America, from Cape Breton Island, Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Quebec south to northern Virginia and Eastern Panhandle of West Virginia, west through the Great Lakes region (including southern Ontario) to eastern Minnesota, northeastern Iowa, and western Pennsylvania (Bleakney 1963; Conant and Collins 1991; Gilhen and Grantmyer 1973; Green and Pauley 1987; Harding 1977; Quinn and Tate 1991).

Wood turtles are usually found where openings in the streamside canopy allow growth of herbaceous plants which provide both food and basking sites. Nesting wood turtles require loose substrate on fully exposed (unshaded) sites, such as sandy banks or sand-gravel bars in streams. When natural openings are unavailable they may use such man-made disturbances as road grades, railroad grades, sand pits, or plowed fields (Harding 1990).
Turtles commonly enter streams at night and individuals occur mainly in streams in spring and fall. Some agricultural operations may be locally beneficial by providing a mixture of different food and cover types near wooded streams (Kaufmann 1992). Wood turtles overwinter in bottoms or banks of streams where water flows all winter, including pools underneath a layer of ice; underwater muskrat burrows, beaver lodges, or over-bank root systems also may be used as winter hibernation (brumation) sites (Ernst 1986).

In general, habitats for the wood turtle include:  along permanent streams during much of each year but in summer may roam widely overland and can be found in a variety of terrestrial habitats adjacent to streams, including deciduous woods, cultivated fields, and woodland bogs, marshy pastures. Use of woodland bogs and marshy fields is most common in the northern part of the range (Ernst 1986). Wood turtles are often associated with the margins of woods and occupy forest edges to balance thermoregulatory and feeding needs (Compton et al. 2002). Western populations are closely associated with water year-round, and eastern populations tend to be more terrestrial in the summer. Hatchlings and small juveniles are much more closely associated with water than are adults (Ernst 1992).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description: M. pennant inhabits coniferous or mixed forests, with high canopy cover (>50%), avoiding open areas, scrub, and hardwood forests. Forest structure is a more powerful indicator of fisher presence than is composition, with snag and stump abundance, coarse woody debris, large diameter trees, and a diversity of tree diameters all positively correlated with fisher use.

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description: Cynomys leucurus habitat consists of arid grasslands and shrub-steppe environments, with wheatgrass, blue grama, junegrass, Indian ricegrass, needle-and-thread grass, broom snakeweed, silver sage, big sagebrush, saltbush, greasewood, rabbitbrush, and prickly pear (Tileston and Lechleitner, 1966; Flath and Paulick, 1979; Menkens et al., 1987; Orabona-Cervoski, 1991; Baker et al., 1999). Within white-tailed prairie dog colonies, shrub cover can range from 0% (Collins and Lichvar, 1986) to 29% (Orabona-Cervoski, 1991), but generally averages <10% (Tilestone and Lechleitner, 1966). Total plant cover ranges from 10 to 82%, with an average of 38%, and tends to be lowest on shrub-dominated sites (Tileston and Lechleitner, 1966; Orabona-Cervoski, 1991). Collins and Lichhvar (1986) reported a maximum vegetation height of 62 cm.

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
Range of this species extends from west Oregon to southern California; Los Angeles County near the coast and in Kern County inland while reportedly absent from the central valley (Behler and King 1979). Lannoo 2005, summarized that approximately 40% of the streams in the Pacific northwest support populations of the foothill yellow-legged frog, 30% in the Cascade Mountains, 30% in south coastal range, and 12% in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada.
Found often in sunbasked banks along streams and rivers of woodlands, chaparral, and forest. Found near riffles and rocky areas. Refuge is offered by silt, vegetation, and stones. Ranges from Mehama on the Santiam River, Marion County, Oregon; In California, it occurs west of crest of Cascades Mountains, south to coastal mountains to San Gabriel River, Los Angeles County, Sierran Nevada foothills (1830m) and in Trinity County at Snow Mount (1940m). Also extends into Baja California, San Pedro Martir in the lower reach of La Grulla Meadow (2040m) (old record (Stebbins 2003). Prefers sunny banks and open woodlands. Streams where it is found are characterized to be gravelly or sandy (Behler and King 1979). Breeding only occurs in streams and rivers (Lannoo 2005).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
The first report of the Inyo Mountains salamander dates from 1973 from two desert springs, French Spring and Long John Canyon on the western slopes of the Inyo Mountains in the Mojave in northern California (Marlow et al. 1979). Following surveys have resulted in the extension of the distribution to more localities within the Inyo Mountains to include the eastern slopes (Giuliani 1990; Papenfuss and Macey 1986; Jennings and Hayes 1994). The northern limits of its distribution is in the Waucoba Canyon at 2285 meters in an east slope and Barrel Spring, a west slope at 1950 meters; the southernmost sites include a west slope in Long John Canyon at 1695 to 1830 meters and Hunter Canyon, an east slope at 490 to 915 meters. The overall elevation range at which populations occur is from 490 in Hunter Canyon to 2590 meters in upper Lead Canyon (Giuliani 1977; Papenfuss 1986). Stebbins (2003) provides an elevational range of 550-2620 meters.
Populations occur in habitat surrounded by large areas desert or semi-desert terrain; this is one of the two species known to occur in desert ecosystems (Lannoo 2005). Thus, the species is restrictedly found in perennial springs and seepages (Green et al. 2013).
Eggs are presumably deposited in moist crevices within the outcrops of the Inyo Mountains; adults and juveniles have been reported under rocks on moist substrates. Populations occur over east-west oriented canyons that dissect both north-south slopes of the Inyo Mountains. Habitat encountered in this region includes northern Mojave Desert with vegetation associations of creosote bush scrub, and lower elevations that grade into Great Basin communities like sagebrush steppe and pinyon juniper woodland at higher elevations (Marlow et al. 1979; Lannoo 2005). Habitat also includes perennial springs and seepages and the associated riparian vegetation usually found within discrete sections of steep canyons. Plants of these areas include willow, wild rose, and coyote brush that grow in dense thickets blocking sunlight from reaching ground level. It has been reported that this species of salamanders are restricted to these habitats where cliffs of solid rock, or talus contact surface flow (Giuliani 1977; Macey and Papenfuss 1991). 
Individuals have been reported resting on wet substrates, under rocks, or sometimes under woody debris, within clumps of moist ferns growing in waterfall splash zones (Giuliani 1977; Papenfuss and Macey 1986). During unfavorable conditions, refugia is offered by the adjacent granitic or limestone outcrops. At least at higher elevations, salamanders are not restricted to riparian or canyon bottom habitats, but are also encountered within pinyon-juniper woodlands.

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
The Kern Canyon slender salamander occurs only in the lower Kern River Canyon in Kern County at the southern range of the Sierra Nevada of California; Localities range from Stork Creek at 455 meters to Clear Creek at 685 meters (Brame and Murray 1968; Hansen 1988). Other localities include Erskine Creek Canyon, which is a tributary to Kern River on the northern region of the neighboring Piute Mountains where they have been reported in small trees at elevations from 890 to 1220 meters. Stebbins (2003) reports an elevational range of up to 1920 meters.
Habitat utilized by this species includes north-facing slopes of pine-oak woodlands along tributary canyons and ravines. Plants that are found in these areas include interior live oak, sycamore, foothill pine, Fremont cottonwood, willow, and California buckeye. Some of the understory vegetation includes nettles, miner’s lettuce, poison oak, Nemophilia species, Phacelia sp., and grasses. It is important to note that salamanders have been found in both, wet margins of seepages and creeks and exposed hillsides in chaparral vegetation (Brame and Murray 1968; Hansen 1988). 
In Clear Creek by Miracle Hot Springs at 685 meters of elevation, salamanders were reported in the slopes covered with interior live oak, foothill pine, yucca, beavertail cactus, and California juniper. In Erskine Creek Canyon at 890-1220 meters, salamanders were associated with foothill pine, canyon live oak, interior live oak, manzanita, deer brush, and Great Basin sagebrush (Lannoo 2005). 

Salamanders were associated with foothill pine, canyon live oak, interior live oak, manzanita, deer brush, and Great Basin sagebrush (Lannoo 2005).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
This species has been recently described and is characterized by a restricted distribution in southeastern Sierra Nevada of California (Wake et al. 2002). The range consists primarily of the region of the Kern Plateau in Tulare County, eastern slopes of the Sierra Nevada well into Indian Wells and Owens valleys in Inyo County, and the Scodie Mountains in Kern County. The elevational range is also varied; 1700-2800m for the localities in Kern Plateau, 1430-2440m in the east slopes of the Sierra, and 1980-2025m in the Scodie Mountains (Lannoo 2005; Wake et al. 2002; Green et al. 2013). Stebbins (2003) has reported an elevational range of 1615-2804 meters.

Adult habitat can include high-elevation coniferous forests, semi-arid pinion pine, and sagebrush associations.

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
This species has a restricted distribution in the southern Santa Lucia Range in north-central San Luis Obispo County in coastal central California (Jockusch et al. 2001; Lannoo 2005). Occurs in the drainages of Paso Robles and Santa Rita creeks (Stebbins 2003). In the north, populations can be found north of the Black Mountain, Paso Robles drainage, and Santa Rita Creeks. Elevational range for this species is 400-640m (Green et al. 2013). Habitat for this species has been characterized as high in elevation, and usually more mesic than surrounding areas (Jockusch et al. 2001).

Identified canopy trees include coast live oak, sycamore, laurel, blue oak, and tan bark oak. But also, dense shrubs such as poison oak has been associated with the species.

Habitat is generally associated with limestone and individuals are found under slabs and irregularly shaped pieces of limestone. Some individuals have been found in small areas covered by mosses or in steep slopes where it appears that individuals use their tail in locomotion (Gorman 1954). “tributaries in Mariposa Co. at 255-800 m (836-2624 ft) elevation” (Zeiner et al. 1988-1990)

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
The relictual slender salamander is only found in the western slopes of the southern Sierra Nevada in California; their distribution begins from the lower Kern River Canyon in Kern County to highlands drained by the Kern and Tule rivers in Tulare County. Localities are found at elevations of 485-730m (Brame and Murray 1968) and in the Greenhorn Mountains at elevations of 1125-2440m. It is important to note that there is only one record in the western limit of the Kern Plateau, east of the Kern River at 2440 meters (Jockusch et al. 1998; Green et al. 2013). This species has been associated with seeps and springs, thus egg deposition sites may be under rocks and logs at the margins of wet microhabitats. Adults have been reported in association with bark rubble, fallen logs, moist conifer forests, and are known to visit springs and seepages that remain moist during the summer. In the Greenhorn Mountains, this species can be found in roadside seepages at elevations of 1675-2130 meters.

Vegetation in these areas includes Ponderosa pine, incense cedar, white fir, black oak, and sugar pine.

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
Although the Shasta salamander was first discovered in 1915, the formal description of the species was provided until their rediscovery in 1950 north of the Shasta Reservoir in northern California (Gorman and Camp 1953). This species occurs near the reservoir in localities east and west of the Sacramento River, and north and south of the Pit River branch of the reservoir at elevations from 300 to 900 meters (Lannoo 2005; Green et al. 2013; Stebbins 2003). 
Most populations occur in areas with limestone rock outcroppings and individuals can be found in moist rock surfaces by night. Other times, individuals are found under rocks, leaf litter, forested areas, and caves.


NW - Habitat of preference is dominated by California black oak (Quercus kelloggii) and pines (Pinus sp.).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
The range of the western spadefoot has been recently reduced to the Great Valley, Coast Ranges, bordering foothills south of Monterey Bay, California expanding into the Mesa de San Carlos in northwest Baja California (Behler and King 1979; Stebbins 2003). Considered extirpated from most of lowland southern California, but persisting in coastal Riverside and Orange Counties, and in inland San Diego County; In the north, present near Black Butte Reservoir, Glenn County (Stebbins 2003). Historical and current distribution, at least up to 1994, are nearly unchanged (Jennings and Hayes 1994 in Lannoo 2005). However, they have been extirpated in areas now converted to urban or agricultural settings (Lanno0 2005).

Habitat is primarily composed of alluvial fans, playas, alkali flats, washes, and floodplains of rivers, foothill grasslands, pine-oak woodlands, and open chaparral, but also reported in mountains and foothills; found specifically in areas of open vegetation and short grasses where soil conditions are usually gravelly or sandy (Stebbins 2003). Can be occasionally found in coastal sage scrub or chaparral nearby breeding pools (Lannoo 2005). Found in shortgrass plains where gravelly and sandy soils predominate such as river floodplains and washes (Behler and King 1979). Most localities are found below 365 meters (Lannoo 2005), while Stebbins 2003 indicate most western spadefoots occur below 910 meters and no higher than 1219; Ervin et al. 2001 reported western spadefoot toads at elevations as high as 1365 meters in San Diego County, California.
Breeding occurs in temporary pools such as vernal lakes, vernal pools, railway and road grades; these isolated pools must last at least 30 days to allow larval development (Lannoo 2005).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
Three subspecies of Spotted Owl (Strix occidentalis) are recognized: Northern Spotted Owl (S. o. caurina), California Spotted Owl (S. o. occidentalis), and Mexican Spotted Owl (S. o. lucida).  Among the three subspecies, the following habitats are used: western hemlock (Tsuga heterophylla), mixed evergreen, mixed conifer, Douglas-fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii), redwood (Sequoia sempervirens), Douglas-fir/hardwood, evergreen hardwood, pine (Pinus)-oak (Quercus), ponderosa pine (Pinus ponderosa), riparian, western redcedar (Thuja plicata), and other forest types, as well as steep, rocky canyons in different parts of its range (Gutierrez et al. 1995).

Gutierrez et al. 1995 reported an elevation limit of up to 1,200 m in the Northwest and 2,700 m in the Southwest (Gutierrez et al. 1995).

Northern Spotted Owls inhabit mature, mixed conifer forests with complex structure for nesting. (Gutierrez et al. 1995).  They roost in portions of forest where canopy closure is high and multiple subcanopy layers exist (Gutierrez et al. 1995).  Foraging habitat is similar to roosting habitat and occurs in managed and unmanaged forests (Gutierrez et al. 1995).  Winter habitat is the same as summer, but use of stands with a larger tanoak (Lithocarpus densiflorus) and oak component was documented in the KIamath region. (Gutierrez et al. 1995).  In northern California, they prefer steep-sided canyons with north-facing slopes (Zeiner et al. 1990).

California Spotted Owls also inhabit forests with complex structure; from low elevation hardwood (oak) forests to high elevation conifer forests.  Like the Northern Spotted Owl, they use areas with lots of tree diameter classes represented and high canopy closure.  The presence of some trees > 90 cm dbh are a critical component of nesting habitat but owls forage in stands without these large trees (Gutierrez et al. 1995).  Some individuals of this subspecies migrate short distances to lower elevation Sierra Nevada hardwood riparian forests (Gutierrez et al. 1995).  They utilize smaller forest stands, with more shrubs and deciduous species (Gutierrez et al. 1995).  

Mexican Spotted Owls are found in forested slopes with rocky outcrops and heavily forested areas in areas of the Southwest (Ganey et al. 2011).  In the Southern Rockies, the most important forest type is mixed-conifer (e.g., Douglas-fir, white fir, ponderosa pine, limber pine, southwestern white pine), but pine-oak, ponderosa pine, and riparian communities are used for roosting and nesting as well.  Gambel oak is an important habitat component and trees with large dbh are utilized for roosting and nesting (Ganey et al. 2011).  Although canopy cover and tree dbh are important, high tree density does not appear to be important for this subspecies (Ganey et al. 2011).  They show a strong preference for old-growth forests and moderate to heavy canopy closure (>40%; Gutierrez et al. 1995 and Ganey et al. 2011).   Rocky canyonlands are suitable habitat for Mexican Spotted Owls in some areas provided they have steep narrow canyons with perennial water.  Such canyonlands usually but don’t always contain patches of trees (conifer or riparian forests; Gutierrez et al. 1995).  In these areas, topography and geology are more influential on owl distribution than vegetation (Ganey et al. 2011).  In the Basin and Range ecoregion, Mexican Spotted Owls occur in evergreen oak woodlands, Madrean pine-oak forests, and Arizona cypress forests (Ganey et al. 2011).

Gutierrez et al. 1995 reported that owls in California require forest blocks of 40-240 ha (100-600 ac) (Gutierrez et al. 1995).  N. Tarr, 12June2013.

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description: The subspecies of red fox, V. v. necator occurs along the Sierra Nevada and Cascade mountain ranges from Nevada, California, and Oregon. They are resticted to high elevation (> 1500 meters)(Jameson and Peeters 2004) forests and subalpine areas near treeline. Forests utilized by the subspecies include red fir and lodgepole pine dominated environments as well as alpine fell-fields in the subalpine zone (Ingles 1965).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
The range of the spotted turtle extends from southern Maine, southern Quebec and southern Ontario, Michigan, northeastern Illinois, central Indiana, central Ohio, and south into southwestern Pennsylvania, and from New England to north-central Florida (Barnwell et al. 1997; Conant and Collins 1991; Ernst et al. 1994; Harding 1997; Hunter et al. 1999; MacCulloch 2002).

Ernst (1976) reported that muskrat burrows in Pennsylvania were used to hibernate during the winter, nocturnal sleeping sites, refuge from danger, and estivation sites during the warm dry months. Haxton and Berrill (1999) reported that hibernation occurred exclusively in bogs in central Ontario and in sphagnum swamps on an island in Georgian Bay, Ontario (Litzgus and Brooks 2000). Eggs are laid in well-drained soil of marshy pastures, in grass or sedge tussock or mossy hummocks, in open areas (e.g., dirt path or road) at edge of thick vegetation, or similar sites exposed to sun. Sandy, sparsely vegetated strips and washouts along agricultural field edges are favorable for nesting (Litzgus and Mousseau 2004).

In general, habitats occupied by the spotted turtle include unpolluted, shallow bodies of water with a soft bottom and aquatic vegetation, such as small marshes, marshy pastures, bogs, fens, woodland streams, swamps, small ponds, vernal pools, and lake margins; in some areas they occur in brackish tidal streams. Ponds bordered by relatively undisturbed meadow or undergrowth are most favorable. Spotted turtles favor waters with a soft bottom and aquatic vegetation and often bask along the water's edge, on brush piles in water, or on logs or vegetation clumps. Moving seasonally among different wetland types and may spend substantial time on land during summer (DeGraaf and Rudis 1983).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
VEGETATION
Stebbins (1985) describes the species as occurring in washes, streams and arroyos in semiarid parts of the southwest, including sandy banks grown to willows, cottonwoods, or sycamores, and also in rocky streams in the pine-oak belt in Arizona and New Mexico. In New Mexico, Bufo microscaphus is usually associated with permanent ponds and rocky streams with shallow water flowing over sandy or rocky bottoms, usually in “unaltered” riparian areas where the vegetation is sycamore or cottonwood within grasslands, pinyon-juniper woodlands, and ponderosa pine forests (Degenhardt et al. 1996). As opposed to most other true toads (Bufo) in New Mexico, this species is less likely to occupy agricultural fields, irrigation ditches, or broad river bottoms (Degenhardt et al. 1996).  In Arizona, Lowe (1964) described the habitat as being rocky stream canyons and floodplains in Arizona Upland desertscrub and evergreen woodlands of the Mogollon Rim. More recently, Price and Sullivan (1988) described habitat in Arizona as relatively shallow permanent or intermittent flowing water over sandy or rocky substrates, from desert to pine-fir forest. In contrast to Degenhardt et al. (1996), Price and Sullivan (1988) state that “artificial habitats, such as irrigated cropland and reservoirs, are increasingly utilized”.  Jones (1988) recorded the following habitats for Bufo microscaphus:  Ponderosa Pine Woodland, Pinyon-Juniper Woodland, Closed Chaparral, Desert Grassland, Mixed Broadleaf Riparian, Cottonwood-Willow Riparian, Juniper / Mixed Shrub Woodland, Mesquite Bosque / floodplain woodland

Vegetation seems relatively unimportant, as the species seems to occupy mid elevation streams of particular water and substrate characteristics within numerous vegetation zones within its range. Schwaner and Sullivan (2005) list cottonwood, willow, and seep willow as common plants found in lower elevation riparian areas used by southwestern toads. 

ELEVATION DESCRIPTION
Stebbins describes the species (including Bufo californicus) as occurring from near sea level to around 6000 ft (1830 m) in the U.S. (and up to 8500 ft/2590 m in Mexico). However, Price and Sullivan (1988) describe the overall range (including Mexico) as from about 90-3025 m. In New Mexico, occurs from 1900-2700 m (Degenhardt et al. 1996). 

HYDROLOGY
Usually associated with permanent ponds and rocky streams with shallow water flowing over sandy or rocky bottoms (Degenhardt et al. 1996). Breeds at the edges of streams or shallows, backwashes, and side pools where flow is minimal (Schwaner and Sullivan 2005). Jones (1988) recorded the species from rocky sites, with permanent water at all sites.

DISTRIBUTION INFORMATION
Stebbins (1985) describes distribution as ranging from southern Nevada to southern Durango, Mexico, and also from coastal southern California to northwest Baja California, occurring in many isolated populations. The western populations are currently regarded as a distinct species, the Arroyo Toad (Bufo californicus). In New Mexico, the species is known from Catron, Grant, and Sierra, and Socorro counties, and is common along the rivers and lakes of the Gila and San Francisco river drainages (Degenhardt et al. 1996). Price and Sullivan (1988) described the distribution as a series of isolated populations along the Mogollon Plateau of SW New Mexico to the Colorado and Virgin River basins in NW Arizona, S Nevada, and SW Utah. Recorded in SW Utah at Zion National Park (Nowak et al. 2002) and SE Utah at Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument (Oliver 2003).  Recent range extensions in Arizona include Pinto Creek at Forest Road 287, the first record on the south side of Roosevelt Lake (Seim 1994), and Clear Creek at Hamilton Crossing, which extended the range 10 km further downstream from Mack’s Crossing (Sullivan 1993) and suggests they may be more widespread in drainages north of the Mogollon Rim (DeMarais and Waters 1994). Schwaner and Sullivan (2005) state that current distribution is likely similar to historic distribution, except that in some areas of Arizona and southern Nevada they are being replaced by Woodhouse’s toads.

MISC.
Key features of habitat within the species’ range appear to be streams that are relatively shallow, and rocky or sandy substrates (Degenhardt et al. 1996, Lowe 1964, Price and Sullivan 1988).  Streamside vegetation is typically willow or cottonwood, with surrounding vegetation ranging from grasslands and “Arizona Upland desertscrub” to Ponderosa Pine forest (Degenhardt et al. 1996, Lowe 1964, Price and Sullivan, 1988).  Sources differ on the tendency of this species to use artificial habitats such as reservoirs and irrigated fields (cf. Degenhardt et al. 1996 and Price and Sullivan 1988).  Jones (1988) recorded the following habitats for Bufo microscaphus:  Ponderosa Pine Woodland, Pinyon-Juniper Woodland, Closed Chaparral, Desert Grassland, Mixed Broadleaf Riparian, Cottonwood-Willow Riparian, Juniper / Mixed Shrub Woodland, Mesquite Bosque / floodplain woodland.  Sources specific to the Southwest GAP area list elevation range as 900 m (based on record south of Roosevelt Lake; Seim 1994) to 2700 m (Degenhardt et al. 1996, for NM).

GAP Modeling Database Parameters.habitat_description:
The southern rubber boa occurs in the San Bernardino Mountains and San Jacinto Mountains of southern California (Stebbins 2003). Most populations are found in the San Bernardino Mountains between Twin Peaks on the west and Green Valley on the East (Stewart 1988). The populations located in the Tehachapi Mountains and Mount Pinos are very similar to this species, but are actually recognized as Charina bottae (northern rubber boa) (Rodriguez-Robles et al. 2001; 2003).

In general, the habitats found in this region include riparian zone, conifer forest, mixed forest, and various woodland types. This species burrows in or using soil, debris, and rotting logs. In the summer, this species is found near moist areas like damp draws, seeps and springs (Loe 1985). Hibernacula takes place in rock outcrops; otherwise cover is provided by rotting logs, stumps, rocks, crevices, and fallen bark (Hoyer and Stewart 2000).

In more detail, the San Bernardino Mountains and San Jacinto Mountains are characterized by patchy chaparral, shubrland, meadows, grassy savannas and coniferous and deciduous semiopen forests and woodlands constituted by Jeffrey pine, yellow pine, sugar pine, black oak, and white fir where this species thrives well inside these forests and forest clearings (Stebbins 2003).

Associations include forests and woodlands constituted by Jeffrey pine, yellow pine, sugar pine, black oak, and white fir. Also found in chaparral, meadows and riparian zones where cover is provided by rocks, crevices, leaf litter, and fallen logs.

rSTSNx-y6.memHandModelNotes:
****No FROM buffer for AMUs; just select bog habitat when adjacent to PMUs. Soils layer would be useful in predicting the distribution of this species. Amy Silvano 25Aug05.

The bog AMUs need to be selected when adjacent to PMUs. This needs to be a regiongrouping/zonal process that must be hand modeled. Previously there was no buffer distance set for AMUs. I changed it to 0 meters which would essentially not select any AMUs. Hand modeled this species instead. MJR 24 October2007.
